title: Between 1 April 2017 and 31 March 2018, will an armed group from Nigeria engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Nigeria?
preds:
In a recent survey conducted in collaboration with NOIPolls; “half of the sampled population believe that the state of security in the country has improved compared to a year ago. However 28% say the security situation has remained the same, while 21% say it has worsened. Further analysis reveals that politically motivated conflicts (28%), land ownership disputes (24%), religious conflicts (23%) and farmer & pastoralist conflicts (22%) are amongst common causes of conflicts across Nigerian communities. (http://allafrica.com/stories/201705290074.html)  The Nigerian government appears to be making progress in regards to armed conflict solutions: 
Tijjani Bande, the Representative of Nigeria to the UN, “noted Resolution 2286 of former Secretary General Ban Ki-Moon, which recommended the swift implementation of this resolution, which platforms to enhance respect for the norms of international humanitarian law.”
“In fulfilment of its obligation, the Nigerian government has set up a presidential committee on North East Initiative to serve as the primary national body. Among others, to enhance the security conditions in the Northeast of the country, facilitate the work of health personnel and ease the movement of medical equipment and supplies.” 
(https://www.businessdayonline.com/nigeria-reaffirms-commitment-protect-civilians-armed-conflicts/)  Despite the growing Biafran movement, it seems unlikely that 1000 civilians will die through this conflict (more than 150 pro-biafrans were killed from August 2015-August 2016) . The acting President Yemi Osinbajo said, during a Biafra Civil forum in Abuja: “They say that secession is the answer to the charges of marginalisation. Brothers and sisters, permit me to differ and to suggest that we’re greater together than apart” (http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2017/05/50-years-nigeria-biafra-secessionist-movement-170529151102396.html). This appears to show an attempt to work with the pro-Biafra movement… In regards to Boko Haram, a report on the Nigeria Today website stated: “Boko Haram’s leader, Abubakar Shekau continues to issue fresh threats of overrunning more Nigerian territories to establish his desired Islamic caliphate”. (http://www.nigeriatoday.ng/2017/06/security-a-conflicting-story-of-sadness-and-joy/). However, with Cameroon, Nigeria, Niger and Chad actively fighting against Boko Haram, with the assistance of US special forces (https://www.armytimes.com/articles/soldiers-deploy-to-central-africa-to-support-the-fight-against-boko-haram), it is unlikely, though not impossible, that Boko Haram will be able to build back up to the level of destruction they were causing in 2014.  On the Herdsmen/farmers conflict: 
“The senate on the 24th May 2017, ordered the Inspector General of Police to urgently take steps to arrest killer herdsmen and all armed killers masquerading as herdsmen in communities, forests and farms throughout the country” (http://www.nigeriatoday.ng/2017/06/security-a-conflicting-story-of-sadness-and-joy/) 
The USAID convoy participated in a close door meeting to “discuss the herdsmen/famers clashes in recent times and proffer lasting solutions to the incessant conflicts” (http://www.nigeriatoday.ng/2017/06/usaid-wades-into-fulani-herdsmenfarmer-conflicts-in-nigeria/) 
With action being taken in this area as well, unless something drastic happens, this should also limit civilian casualties.

Boko Haram would be the usual suspect for systematic killings in Nigeria.  Since Boko Haram showed up on the radar as a legitimate terrorist organization, it has yet to carry out the systematic killing of 1,000 or more people in one incident.  The Nigerian Army and the UN are having military success against Boko Haram, as well.  I predict no armed group will systematically kill 1,000 or more people in Nigeria between April 1, 2017 - March 31, 2018.  Boko Haram seems to be following the ISIS abroad tactic of small scale terrorist attacks as their main means of combat.  The major risk area I see is the borderlands and the presence of Boko Haram in other countries leaking into less secure regions of Nigeria.

I'm surprised the average is not higher on this one. Maybe I'm missing something, but 1,000 seems likely. The CFR Nigeria Security Tracker is very useful for this question. http://www.cfr.org/nigeria/nigeria-security-tracker/p29483
Water and famine will play a big issue the worst its been

Dropping forecast slightly as the Nigerian government has reportedly taken some steps to reduce violence through peaceful methods. 
“The Kaduna State House of Assembly passed into law a bill to provide for the establishment of the State Peace Commission. The functions of the commission shall be to engage in conflict monitoring and mitigation activities, including organising regular joint interactive meetings in communities, designing and implementing peace advocacy programmes in the mass media, as well as carrying out peace advocacy work in schools, public places and worship centres” (http://allafrica.com/stories/201704270276.html) 
This will involve the Nigerian government working with international organisations and agencies involved in peace mediation in order to help the commission carry out its work. Of course, this only matters when the Commission put words into action.  In relation to conflict between herdsmen and farmers; “the federal government has proposed a national conference to address the protractive and bloodletting conflicts between herdsmen and farmers.” The Minister of Agriculture and Rural Development (Chief Audu Ogbeh) has said the national conference will bring together major stakeholders to analyse the crises, which would be held in the second week of June. (https://www.thisdaylive.com/index.php/2017/04/25/fg-to-hold-national-conference-on-herdsmen-farmers-conflict-in-june/)  I’ve been reading into the conflict in Biafra (Niger River Delta region) and found this report to be very insightful; it provides analysis of all the areas of major conflict in Nigeria: http://www.globalresearch.ca/hybrid-war-can-wreak-havoc-across-west-africa-2/5584061
The general gist of the article is what the impact of having three main ethno-regional identities has on the country. “The general idea is that the reconsolidating of ethno-regional identities around the Hausa-Fulani, Yoruba and Igbo peoples could set into motion the uncontrollable centrifugal process of Identity Federalism or separatism.”  What can be seen happening in the Biafra region is there are 3 main groups; “Niger Delta Avengers”, “Movement for the Actualization of the Sovereign State of Biafra (MASSOB)” and “Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger Delta (MEND)”, who are divided due to their competing interests.
‘Operation Crocodile Smile’ was launched by the government in August 2016 to “bring back law and order to the southeast”. In response to this, the Niger Delta Avengers launched “Operation Crocodile Tears” to fight back against the government. 
In relation to Hybrid War “there appears to be an ethnic divided between the Avengers and the other Biafra militant with attempts having been made to link the Ijaw (indigenous people to the Niger Delta region) with the Avengers. Whether or not the Ijaws are the main driving force behind the avengers, this is how they are being portrayed which can indicate two pertinent things. Firstly, Operation Crocodile Smile could be interpreted as targeting the Ijaw, thus raising expected claims of ‘ethnic cleansing’ and ‘genocide’ if the conflict heats up. Secondly, because of what appears to be a divide between the Ijaw, Igbos and and Itsekiri, there’s a chance for the government to exacerbate whatever splits are currently existing in order to isolate active militants by turning their neighbours against them”.  Unless the Ijaw publicly claim to back the Avengers, I cannot see this transpiring into a genocide due to the international condemnation that would follow. Nigeria cannot afford to lose international funding, especially with the “at risk of famine” conditions currently occurring in the northeast.
Boko Haram seems to have been losing ground.  As a result, there is a chance they will become even more violent, engaging in a campaign of killing to prove their relevance.

AB747 offers some good analysis. However, Boko Haram has been largely brought under control by state security forces. 
--https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/world/nigeria-boko-haram/
They're still a threat, and if security forces are stretched thin by rebel activity in other parts of the country, things could get worse. Another risk factor is the food insecurity in Nigeria (it's likely the UN or WHO will declare a famine sometime soon).  I'll have to do more research into the various militia and terrorist groups operating in Nigeria and update when I have the info.

Civilians will die in Nigeria, Boko Haram has been fighting a long time and government security forces have ramped up. Millions displaced and lots of food insecurity. The only question is will it be in targeted numbers to resolve this as a yes.

Decreasing forecast slightly after reading this article: https://issafrica.org/iss-today/less-armed-conflict-but-more-political-violence-in-africa
ISS article: “The HIIK conflict barometer 2016 finds that most high- and low- intensity wars are drifting away from coup attempts and power grabs compared to previous years, and the continent is witnessing more ‘violent crises’, which are associated with fewer deaths, refugees and internally displaced persons” With Trump set to sell Embraer A-29 Super Tucanos to Nigeria to aid the fight against Boko Haram (https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2017/04/10/u-s-looks-to-sell-ground-attack-aircraft-to-nigeria-report-says/?utm_term=.093f9d84f900), I think it is unlikely that Boko Haram will be able to increase on the number of civilians killed last year - 790 civilian deaths in 2016 ((http://www.acleddata.com/trend-4-trends-in-violence-by-country-in-2016/) - provided the Nigerian military use the aircraft strategically and can maintain them.

Quite unlikely the Boko Haram will rebound to this level. Fulani herder violence could reach this level in aggregate, though do you count those as a single group or many?: this is quite decentralized.

While Boko Haram represents a likely candidate for reaching the threshold, the definition of the question excluding "unrelated executions of individuals" reduces the overall probability; thus only a 10%
A corrupt government, religious differences and an extremist group Boko Haram that is killing more people than ISIS. The only question is if a 1,000 will be systematically killed.

Boko Haram in Nigeria is targeting civilians, well they're targeting everyone indiscriminately. They kill thousands of civilians every year, and while they have been weakened and pushed out of a lot of territory, they are still a powerful force in Nigeria and I fear they will kill thousands more before they're defeated. Death totals are from the Uppsala Conflict Data Program, link below. http://ucdp.uu.se/#/exploratory
I just can't see this happening.  Nigeria plays too much of a role for China and for Europe.
Mass starvation is happening. Both the military and Boko Haram threaten peoples livlihoods and precarious access to water, but prevention of free movement are inhibiting access to care.
Boko Haram attacks are down significantly and the group has been both divided and degraded, but it is always possible or a couple of big attacks to bump up against this threshold.

I have hope in Nigeria to reverse some of its brutal behavior, right now it seems that the movement to get women in office is a good step to focus in participation and not in petty warlords fiefdom brutal fights.

“25.7% off all civilian fatalities occurred in Nigeria, making it the most dangerous African country for civilians” (http://www.acleddata.com/trend-4-trends-in-violence-by-country-in-2016/)  The Fulani ethnic militia poses the biggest threat to civilians in Nigeria. The Fulani were “responsible for a reported 854 civilian fatalities in 2016 (up from 546 in 2015)” (ACLED, Real-time analysis of African Political Violence, February 2017 - http://www.acleddata.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/ACLED_Conflict-Trends-Report-No.55-February-2017_pdf..pdf) “Many of the Fulani attacks, most prevalent during 2016 in the states of Benue, Kaduna and Taraba, have also resulted in large displacements of people and often burning down of homes and villages. Disputes behind the violence allegedly focus on the use of resources such as farmlands, grazing areas, and water, with both sides claiming grievances against the other.” (ACLED report)  Boko Haram were the second most deadliest armed group to Nigerian civilians in 2016. “responsible for 790 reported civilian fatalities in 2016” (ACLED report). Given the amount of territory that the group lost last year, it is unlikely that they will be able to top the 2016 figure past 1000 casualties - unless they have a repeat of the massacre in Baga (https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jan/09/nigeria-baga-massacre-boko-haram-1-year-on) 
Trump is upping military presence in many countries across the world, including some African countries e.g. Somalia. “The Pentagon has allocated about $250 million over two years to help train the armies and security forces of North, Central and West African countires” (https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/19/world/africa/trump-special-forces-navy-seals.html). With the help of US special forces in Cameroon, Chad, Niger and Nigeria, Boko Haram will be limited to expanding territory. It is my understanding that Boko Haram are engaged in a campaign that systematically kills civilians as the Barnawi faction of the terror group have stated “it is moving away from attacks that target muslim civilians” (ACLED report) “Famine Early War System Network (FEWS NET) predicts a credible risk of severe food insecurities in Nigeria…This could lead to greater instability across central and northern areas of Nigeria, which in turn puts pressure on Nigerian security services and offers new opportunities for Boko Haram to press over-extended forces” (ACLED report). FEWS NET is an agency supported by USAID - which is at risk of a 28% budget cut in Trumps new budget proposal; “Reduces funding to UN and affiliated agencies, including peacekeeping”. Preventing a famine in Nigeria depends largely on countering terrorism - if the USAs funding to the UN decreases by the end of 2017, the UN will have to decide which of the countries with conflict are most likely to receive peacekeeping missions. 
However, the new US administrations budget also states: “Allows for significant funding of humanitarian assistance, including food aid, disaster and refugee program funding. This would focus funding on the highest priority areas…”(https://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/whitehouse.gov/files/omb/budget/fy2018/2018_blueprint.pdf page 33). Given the UN’s estimate of 4 famines in 2017, UN Humanitarian Chief O’brien said “We stand at a crucial point in history. Already at the beginning of the year we are facing the largest humanitarian crisis since the creation of the UN” (http://edition.cnn.com/2017/03/11/africa/un-famine-starvation-aid/) it is possible with a famine only affecting 120000, compared to millions in other countries, they will get the least support in terms of food aid.  If any forecasters disagree with my comment in answering the question please let me know!
1000 isn't a very big number in Nigeria
